title: Single-gene short-term CRISPR ko viability assay

authors.name: Tsukasa Shibue
authors.affiliation: Cancer Program, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

protocol.title: Single-gene short-term CRISPR ko viability assay
protocol.title_html: Single-gene short-term CRISPR ko viability assay

source.description: (Day 0) Template/Planning: create a copy of the "Viability Assay Optimization" template and fill out the information.

(Day 0) Make Viral Master Plate: prepare (a) master plate(s) of BRD003 lenti-virus that contains the following volume of virus per 40 uL of total volume
ABCDEFGHIJKLM
1123456789101112
2A            
3B 01.251.251.251.251.251.251.251.251.25 
4C 02.52.52.52.52.52.52.52.52.5 
5D 0555555555 
6E 0101010101010101010 
7F 0202020202020202020 
8G 0404040404040404040 
9H            
* NOTE- up to 4 cell types/one master plate; if seeding > 4 cell types, make multiple master plates

ABCDEFGHIJKLM
1123456789101112
2A            
3B 01.251.251.251.251.251.251.251.251.25 
4C 02.52.52.52.52.52.52.52.52.5 
5D 0555555555 
6E 0101010101010101010 
7F 0202020202020202020 
8G 0404040404040404040 
9H
Prepare (# of cell types) x 400 uL of BRD003 virus
Fill column 2, rows B-G and columns 3-11, rows B-F (wells w. black numbers) with (# of cell types) x 50 uL of R10 medium
Aliquot (# of cell types) x 100 uL of BRD003 virus into columns 3-11, row G (wells w. red numbers)
Transfer (# of cell types) x 50 uL of virus-containing medium from columns 3-11, row G to columns 3-11, row F and mix well (not well itself but its content); change chips of multichannel pipetter
Transfer (# of cell types) x 50 uL of virus-containing medium from columns 3-11, row F to columns 3-11, row E and mix well (not well itself but its content); change chips of multichannel pipetter
Transfer (# of cell types) x 50 uL of virus-containing medium from columns 3-11, row C to columns 3-11, row B and mix well (not well itself but its content)

(Day 0) Cell Seeding: seed the numbers of cells in 100 uL medium (containing 5.6 ug/mL polybrebne [H9268, SIgma-Aldrich]) indicated in this table in two 96 well plates (per cell line):
ABCDEFGHIJKLM
1(Plate I)123456789101112
2A            
3B 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
4C 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
5D 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
6E 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
7F 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
8G 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
9H            
ABCDEFGHIJKLM
1(Plate II)123456789101112
2A            
3B 2000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
4C 2000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
5D 2000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
6E 4000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
7F 4000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
8G 4000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
9H

ABCDEFGHIJKLM
1(Plate I)123456789101112
2A            
3B 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
4C 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
5D 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
6E 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
7F 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
8G 1000100010001000100010001000200020002000 
9H

ABCDEFGHIJKLM
1(Plate II)123456789101112
2A            
3B 2000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
4C 2000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
5D 2000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
6E 4000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
7F 4000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
8G 4000200020002000400040004000400040004000 
9H
make 6 x (# of cell type) mL medium containing 5.6 ug/mL polybrene (this is ‘A’).
make a suspension of 40K cell/10 mL medium (w/ 5.6 ug/mL polybrene) (this is ‘B’).
Aliquot 75 uL of A into Plate I, columns 2-8 .
Aliquot 50 uL of A into Plate I, columns 9-11; Plate II, columns 2-5 (except for 2E, 2F, 2G).
Aliquot 25 uL of B into Plate I, columns 2-8.
Aliquot 50 uL of B into Plate I, columns 9-11; Plate II, columns 2-5 (except for 2E, 2F, 2G).
Aliquot 100 uL of B into Plate II, columns 6-11 and 2E, 2F, 2G.
(Day 0) Infection: transfer 40 uL of (virus-containing) medium from the virus master plate to the corresponding well of cell-seeded plate; centrifuge at 900 x g, 1.5h at 37°C.
(Day 1) Medium change/Puro selection: change medium with 200 uL of fresh medium - Puro (+): For only Plate 1, columns 6-8 and Plate II, columns 3-5, 9-11, use 2 ug/mL Puromycin-containing medium.
(Day 3) change medium (Puro (-) or (+)).
(Day 5) change medium (Puro (-) or (+)).
(Day 7) CTG measurement: Perform the CellTiter-Glo protocol provided by Promega and paste the CTG values for each cell line under the "Assay Dev" tab of the "Viability Assay Optimization" template.

For each of the seeding densities – i.e., 1000, 2000, 4000 cells/well --, determine the minimum volume of virus that yields (mean CTG value of Puro (+) wells) > 0.8 x (mean CTG value of Puro (-) wells): Set the mean Puro (-) CTG value for this volume of virus as C1000 (or C2000, C4000); check if the C value determined here is larger than ‘0.7 x (corresponding mean CTG value of infection/Puro (-) sample)’.
If C4000≥ 1.8 x C2000, use 4000 cells/well (if not, go to 11).
If 1.5 x C2000 ≤ C4000 < 1.8 x C2000, use 3000 cell//well (if not, go to 12).
If C2000≥ 1.8 x C1000, use 2000 cells/well (if not, go to 13).

Determine the minimum volume of virus that gives (mean CTG value of Puro (+) wells) > 0.8 x (mean CTG value of Puro (-) wells) for the detemined seeding density of corresponding cells. If an interpolated number of cells is used (3000 or 1500 cells/ well), take the mean virus volume for the "4000" and "2000" values. Based on this virus volume (which reflects sensitivity to viral infection/viral toxicity), categorize cell lines used for a single project (usually around 10 cell lines of varying lineages) into 3 classes: HIGH/MEDIUM/LOW infection sensitivity. When you prepare a set of virus for viability assay, pick one cell line from each class and titrate all the virus against these cell lines (see an example below):
AB
1sensitivityExample cell lines
2LOWSNU503_colon, JIMT1_breast, HCC95_lung, KYSE410_esophagus
3MEDSW837_colon, HCC15_lung, KYSE450_esophagus
4HIGHHCC202_breast, AU565_breast, SKBR3_breast, ZR751_breast

3MEDSW837_colon, HCC15_lung, KYSE450_esophagus
4HIGHHCC202_breast, AU565_breast, SKBR3_breast, ZR751_breast

source.title: Titration of Virus for Viability Assay

source.description: Measure the titers of 9 types of virus prepared/aliquoted as below, using 3 representative cells lines -- 1 from HIGH, MEDIUM, and LOW infection sensitivity (as identified by the Week1 'Assay Dev' [above].

source.title: Titration of Virus for Viability Assay

source.description:
Prepare virus for each of the:
  • 3 negative controls (BRD003-sgLacZ/-sgCH2-2/-sgAAVS1)
  • 3 positive controls (BRD003-sgPOLR2D/sgSF3B1/-sgKIF11)
  • 3 target-specific guides (BRD-003-sgXXX-A/-sgXXX-B/-sgXXX-C)
Prepare virus in 1x15cm dish; this will yield approx 17 mL of virus. Aliquot the virus into 1.5 mLx11 vials and assemble as below:

source.description:
Pick 3 cell lines representing HIGH/MEDIUM/LOW infection sensitivity based on the ‘Assay Development’ result
e.g. SNU503(LOW), SW837 (MEDIUM), HCC202(HIGH)

source.title: Titration of Virus for Viability Assay

source.description:
Determine the amount of virus (X) that fulfills both:
A) CTG ​virus=x, Puro(-) / CTG​ virus=0, Puro(-) ≥​0.8​,
B) ​CTG​ virus=x, Puro (+) / CTG​ virus=0, Puro(-) ≥​0.8

source.title: Titration of Virus for Viability Assay

source.description: When multiple virus amounts fulfill the above criteria, pick the amount of virus that gave the largest CTG Puro(+) value. This will usually match the peak of the Puro (+) CTG curve.

source.title: Titration of Virus for Viability Assay

Before starting the assy, you should know: Seeding Density and Infection Sensitivity (for each cell line tested) and Viral Titer (for each virus tested).
(Day 0) Create a copy of the "CTG normalization template" and fill out the information (there are 6 lines per template; if testing > 6 cell lines, create multiple sheets).
Cell seeding; seed # of cells in accordance with the result from the seeding density measurement; One 96-well plate (rows B-G; columns 1-11).
(Day 1) Infection
Dilute Virus with 10% FBS RPMI; use the "Virus Calculation for CTG Assay" template to calculate how much virus/medium to be mixed.

Aliquot 325 uL of diluted virus to single row (columns 1-11)/cell line of the Master Plate(s).

Add 50 uL of virus from Master Plate to corresponding wells (in rows B-G) of cell-seeded plate.
Spin plate at 900 x g for 1.5 hours at 37C.
(for sensitive cells) replace medium with 100uL of fresh cell-specific medium right after spinning.

(Day 2) Selection: Replace medium with 100 uL of fresh medium [for antibiotics (-)] or antibiotics-containing medium [for antibiotics (+)] .

(Day 5) Medium change: Replace medium with 100 uL of fresh medium [for antibiotics (-)] or antibiotics-containing medium [for antibiotics (+)]
(Day 7) CTG Assay

Final CTG values from a plate reader can be copied and pasted directly into "CTG Normalization Template. The results for the final assay will be normalized such that 0 is equal to an average of our negative (cutting) controls and -1 is equal to the average of our positive controls.

source.title: Titration of Virus for Viability Assay

source.description:
Make virus 'Master Plate':
Create a master plate (enough virus for both seeded plates) by serial diluting pure virus in R10 with a multichannel pipette:
ABCDEFGHIJKL
1------------------------------------------------
2----Med150150150150150150150150150ul
3----Med150150150150150150150150150----
4----Med150150150150150150150150150----
5----Med150150150150150150150150150----
6----Med150150150150150150150150150----
7----Med300300300300300300300300300----
8------------------------------------------------
  1. Fill row G (columns 3-11) with indicated amount of virus.
  2. Fill rows B-F (columns 3-11) with indicated amount of medium (eg. R10).
  3. Fill rows B-F (columns 3-11) with indicated amount of medium (eg. R10).
  4. Transfer half the volume from row G to row F and mix well.
  5. transfer half the volume from row F to row E and mix well.
  6. Transfer half the volume from row E to row D and mix well.
  7. Transfer half the volume from row D to row C and mix well.
  8. Transfer half the volume from row C to row B and mix well.

source.title: Titration of Virus for Viability Assay

source.description: (Day 0) Infection: Transfer 40 uL of virus to cell-seeded plates form the corresponding well in Master Plate. Centrifuge at 900 x g, 37-degree for 1.5h.
Replace medium with 100 uL/well of warm 10% FBS RPMI
Add 25 uL/well of CellTiter-Glo Reagent (Promega, G7573)
Shake on a plate shaker for 30 min RT
Read luminescence using a plate reader (eg., EnVision, PerkinElmer, #2105-0010)

materials.name: Corning® 96-well Flat Clear Bottom White Polystyrene TC-treated Microplates 20 per Bag with Lid S

description:
The Cancer Dependency Map Project is using genome-scale CRISPR loss-of-function screens on a large number of cancer models to systematically identify selective genetic dependencies, which in turn represent potential therapeutic targets. As we identify potential targets through this project, it is becoming increasingly important to have a robust validation strategy to de-risk individual targets before embarking on costly therapeutic projects.
Here we describe an experimental strategy for assessing the short-term viability effect after knocking out a gene of interest via CRISPR/Cas9 using a commercially-available luminescent cell viability assay reagent (Cell-titer Glo [Promega]) in a 96-well format. The robustness and reproducibility of this assay are critically dependent on two experimental parameters: seeding density of the cells and the lentivirus infection efficiency. We provide standardized protocols for the rigorous determination of both of these parameters.
In addition, given that CRISPR-mediated gene knockout penetrance differ across cell lines, the use of standardized controls is necessary for the comparative assessment of the strength of the dependency across cell lines. Moreover, there is a non-specific toxicity effect resulting from the DNA double-strand breaks caused by the CRISPR/Cas9 system. It is therefore important to use sgRNAs targeting intragenic regions, which serve as negative controls to account for this non-specific toxicity. We have tested and identified the sequences of negative and positive sgRNAs controls (pan-essential genes) that can be used to scale the cell viability read-outs.
Finally, we also provide a series of templates to record and normalize the data produced throughout this assay.
